bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ignacio Alvare, June 24, 1940

div1.p: Hench discusses the identification of Camp Lazear site.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ignacio Alvare, June 24, 1940
div1.opener:
leave on desk.
June 24, 1940
Dr. Ignacio Alvare
Calle 9
304 (Vedado)
Havana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Alvare:
div1.p:
A couple of months ago I visited Havana, in connection
with some historical researches which I am carrying on, pertain-
ing to the work of Dr. Finlay, Dr. Reed and his commission on
yellow fever, and visited the supposed site of Camp Lazear.
For certain reasons I have some doubts that the place that they
have marked is really the original site of Camp Lazear. I had
some discussions with the Secretary of Sanitation and also with
the Secretary of War of the Cuban government, and they told me
that the present site of Camp Lazear was located by means of
a photograph given them by Dr. Alberto Recio. This photograph
shows a small framboyant tree and a shack. The tree still remains,
but the shack is no longer there. Dr. Recio tells me that you
gave him this photograph and could tell me something about its
identity and how this site came to be chosen as the site of Camp
Lazear. I would appreciate this information very greatly.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
